title: Ex-wife chastises father for not comforting 15-year-old daughter more after she stole her 16-year-old stepsister's heirloom necklace: 'Any more comforting would be coddling, and she needs to learn from this'
description: The fact that you shouldn't take something that isn't yours without asking isn't okay is one of the simplest lessons you learn in your life, and, really, it's best that this lesson is learned as early as possible. Now, that doesn't mean that we won't grow up and make mistakes or cave into that devil on our shoulder every now and again and help ourselves to something we know we really shouldn't, but in those times we'll at least know we've done something wrong and hopefully the act itself won't be so severe. There is, of course, a gradient of severity involved here; "borrowing" someone's pen with or without asking because you forgot yours and then never giving it back is not the same thing as "borrowing" someone's car.
author: Brad Dickson

html:
While taking anything without asking is bad, the value makes it worse, and keepsakes and other things that have a priceless sentimental value to the owner are by far the worst things to take. No insurance or payout is ever going to cover the cost of what was lost with an irreplaceable heirloom.

So, when this teen took an interest in her step-sister's necklace she gave into her magpie tendencies and decided to “borrow" it because she thought it was nice and wanted to wear it. When the necklace was spotted as missing by its owner the teen's story was that she had misplaced it somewhere, which presented as a red flag to readers.

Readers supposed that she might have been jealous of the item and the importance that it held to her stepsister— signifying an unbreakable bond with a deceased relative. They thought she might have had more malicious intentions for the necklace but had second thoughts.
